name: Fran Bow
description: Fran Bow is a creepy adventure game that tells the story of Fran, a young girl struggling with a mental disorder and an unfair destiny.
minimum_requirements: OS: 7+ Processor: 1.7 GHz Dual Core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 260, ATI Radeon 4870 HD, or equivalent card with at least 512 MB VRAM Storage: 600 MB available space Sound Card: DirectX Compatible Sound Card

reviews.review_text: I'm just at the beginning of the game but I must say that it already has more than impressed me. The art style is just beautiful and I just happen to really like the concept of this game. It is cute but at the same time disturbing and cruel, dealing with serious and complex topics like mental illness, psychological and physical abuse an murder. Additionally, this is full of pretty weird and morbid creatures that reminds me of Tim Burton's work.   It is clearly visible that this game was made with a lot of care and love. As far as I understood, Killmonday barely consists of two members who created this little gem all by themselves. This leaves me even more impressed and you can clearly tell the difference by the personal effort they put in it in comparision to big game developers who create games in mass production.  So if you like point and click adventures that are not AAA-title-polished but have their very own beautiful style and if you have strong nerves to deal with the twisted themes in this game, I can only recommend you to buy this game and help Killmonday sell this game well so we can look forward to many new interesting games from them in the future!

Fran Bow is a very unique game. What starts as surreal and terrifying only escaltes. It took me aback several times with how creative and strange it could be. Beautiful music, art, and writing all come together to make a game unlike any I've played before. It's not for the faint of heart, with geninely upsetting themes like suicide, abortion, medical abuse, sexual abuse etc, so be wary of that.  The puzzles stumped me several times but, never to the point where I gave up. There's always just enough information (except for one or two parts) to keep you going, to keep searching.  A cross between charming and bizzare, between horror and fantasy, this is a lovely game.  It reminds me of The Cat Lady for many reasons; dark story, creative themes, point and click etc.   The ending left me feeling a bit...lacking? I think I understand everything that happened and it is nice to have a 'happy' ending and know that Fran will be okay, but I guess as the player I would like to see her being alright.

I am not kidding when I say, BUY THIS GAME!! It lives up to the psychological horror tag, but it is so much more. The artwork is fantastic, the animations are intricate and really add to the atmosphere of the game. This game is really well written, polished and executed. If you are looking for a game to get all kinds of wrapped up in, that will make you think, wonder and sit in awe. BUY THIS GAME!
game is deeper than inception

Fran Bow is one of those games that changes your opinion of life after you play it. Very few games have achieved making me feel this way about them. The gameplay is very gory, but contains a concept that was completely new to me and facinating in the way it is executed. Playing as a 11 year old girl struggling within her own mind. Being told everything through direct thoughts made it much more immersive. I never really knew who to trust. Every object had several sentences of dialogue. I triple clicked on every object, read everything there was to read to see all of her reactions. I'm also planning on re-playing this again to catch what I might have missed which I rarely do. That's how magnificent of a game this is. Playing as Fran really made me enjoy every minute of it too. What I didn't expect is you will play as other characters as you go along when Fran isn't available. Her opinion on simple objects made this game so much more interesting for me. There is plenty of symbolism that tell side stories of the children you're first introduced to. I am so happy Killmonday took the time to include them within the story. It really gave a great deal of emotion and helped influence the mood. The mystery is what really kept me playing. Answers are weaved within the story instead of only at the end. New mysterys are made when old ones are answered. Small hints are everywhere but usually vague, you'll understand them eventually. I really enjoyed making those connections. The puzzles can be difficult but to me makes them much more satisfying to solve. Some unexpected mini games appeared which made playing very entertaining. If you're into mysterious and gory point and click adventures you seriously NEED to get this game, it is outstanding!

So to be fair i did not know what to expect of Fran Bow. But after the first cut scene and realise that there was so many horror element in the lore of the game that i knew that i was about to experience something special. Creepy at first, we are presented with real life horror element such has ♥♥♥♥ and pedofila. Fran Bow does a great job in subtaly integrating these dark theme into its lore without overdoing it..  There was a time were artistic stop motion was a thing (wait you will get were i am going with this) were it was all about the craftsmanship and the facial expression coming to life frame by frame. Well Fran bow would have been an amazing stop motion movie. The character design are reminiscent of Tim burtons early work (Yes there was a time were my friend Burton was actually a good filmmaker) and the The creatures design are absolutely incredible. But i am happy that Fran bow is a game because it is reminding me of why i love the stop motion art in general.  Back to game at hand, i will say this if you are a fan of american mcgee Alice and you have been craving for a proper sequel and hate tim burton version of alice in wonderland. Then Fran bow should be the does of medication you have been craving for.   With that said there are it's fault some of the puzzle designed are weirdly designed. 95% percent can be solved if you pay attention to the level designed but i found my self looking at a guide for 2 of them that i won't detail them because i wouldn't want to reveal any spoiler. With that said that a problem with 90 % of the point and click genre in general so that not a big issue. Some of the mini game are fun but feel force and unnecessary, they do offer some interesting art style.   9.1/10 Verdict: Dark, Creepy and Underated. If you are a fan of point and click games Fran Bow is worth a full price Steam purchase.

Donnie Darko meets Alice in Wonderland.  This game is thoroughly bizarre, creepy bloody, cute, and tragic. The storyline and mystery keeps you constantly interested and making theories about what's going on.

One of the best indie games I have every played. This game is a piece of art. The story, the music, the characters, the events, the chapters. Everything is just so beautifully well crafted. The story is so weird but beautiful at the same time. You'll want more even after you complete the game.

I love so many things about this game, the art style is beautiful to watch and even the horror elements are really pretty to watch too, most horror games today focus more to make there horror elements super scary and make you look away but Fran Bow doesn't go for that path. The Point and Click mechanics are perfect and simple, it does not weird you out with hard controls or anything. Killmonday has smash all the good stuff of Point and Click games and make something very fun the play. I found the story very sweet, cool and sad but beautiful. At the end I really care about Fran and to see her happy after all the misery she has to put up with. The story has a bit of everything itself, is not just only psychological horror, there also some other things that are very different of what we see in the beginning but it holds to the story and stills connected to it.  I recommend Fran Bow to everybody that loves video games that try go for something new and exciting and to connect to people in a very personal way. If you are one of those people that love art in video games, you have a lot of see here... Everythings has so much detail, is crazy!!*

I managed to complete the game entirely and thought it was extremely amazing, honestly. It includes many serious circumstances aswell as being a well styled and cool puzzel game it has a lovely idea based around time itself, human perception and our darkest fears. The story line is vague but still comes through at the end. There is always a plot twist or surprise waiting and all in all one of the bestest adventure games Ive ever played. Then after all those awesome features it also has the aspect of horror. Literally quite spooky at times. No actual Jump scares or anything, mainly blood etc aswell as having to work through the horror by taking the pills given to you in the game to work through puzzels is another amazing aspect of the game too. I hope everyone else enjoys this game as much as I have. I fully Recommend this game.

*Semi-Spoilers*  I apologize to the creators for not recommending this obvious labor of love. Fran Bow has a lot going for it and earns the (nowadays) rare distinction of being a game I actually played until the end. Which means that amidst all these hundreds of games that fail to hold my attention or engage me sufficiently to be 'beaten' this one persevered only to reward me with... nothing.  No conclusion, no reveal, no explanation, no closure.  Some people enjoy this sort of thing; going online afterwards to discuss their interpretations and theories about events that unfolded. I can even agree with this and relate to it up to a point. I just can't help but feel Fran Bow took it a bit too far leaving _everything_ up to the player. Was it all a dream? Was half of it a dream? 25% dream? Is there one single 'fact' in this story anchored to reality or is everything fluid and left to your imagination?   When I read a novel I like to imagine that the author had this burning desire to share their story with me; that everything they put into writing was more or less important to the story or the setting or the mood. There will be some ambiguity or some uncertainty - certain facts will be left up to your imagination and make the story better for it.  Here, you might as well just grab a cup of your favorite beverage, sit down comfortably and use these following keywords to make up your own story in your head:  Little Girl, Insane Asylum, Dead Parents, Medicine, Psychosis,  Did you do it? There you go, whatever you made up in your head can most likely fill in for what 'actually' happened in Fran Bow.

This Game is a gorgeous point & Click Game with a very rich story and great atmospheric gameplay. I never saw a better game here on Steam! It reminded me alot on Alice Madness Returns and because of that I felt very welcome, very quickly.   The Options are easy to set up and it runs really well. I had no problems with the game whatsoever.   The Puzzles are in different difficulties and sometimes are hard for me to crack. But yet still it was alot of fun to do them!  I think this game is a must to every Alice Madness Returns & / or Point & Click Fan.  If you are however not a fan oh those kinda games, I think you should try it out either way. The Story is scary but also very nice. It sometimes will proof you wrong when you think you are right.  If you are easily scared as in you can't sleep for months after a jump scare I do not recommend playing this game.

Horror as a genre requires a particularly elegant approach to be successful. It is certainly possible to scare someone through blunt manipulation of disturbing images and a reliance on proven tropes, but horror that lingers, sticking to its audience like the aftermath of a bad dream, that takes something more. To its credit, Fran Bow initially understands this to a level that is truly chilling. But as developer Killmonday Games takes on more and more plotlines, shuffling the player deeper into an incomprehensible madness, Fran Bow falls inside the depths of a convoluted narrative mess from which it is never able to crawl back out of.  Beginning within the bloodstained hallways of a children’s mental institution, Fran Bow has access to no shortage of unsettling narratives and images to pull from, drawing heavily from horrific historical medical practices and occult imagery to craft an aggressively grim premise. 10 years old going on 11, the eponymous Fran Bow is plagued by violent images of her parent’s slaughter. Trapped now in a categorically inhumane asylum, her day to day life consists of being carted from psychiatric evaluations to routine drug administrations, forcing her madness back into her mind and leaving her in a vegetative state. Her one out from this hellish existence comes in the form of a bottle of red pills, which upon ingesting allows Fran to see her grotesque visions manifest in the real world, in the process instructing her on how to escape and setting her off on a quest to find her cat and only friend, Mr. Midnight.  Setting aside its narrative baggage, Fran Bow operates on what can be considered two distinct levels. The first is that of a decidedly traditional adventure game, with a heavy focus on jerry-rigging items together in order to solve an inordinate amount of inscrutable puzzles. Fran Bow makes little sense by design, but while this is largely excusable in a narrative drawing heavily from the likes of Alice in Wonderland (and even more so the macabre video game reimagining, Alice: Madness Returns) it effectively turns each puzzle into an inventory jigsaw puzzle as the player is left to attempt to combine items until something clicks into place. This is made all the worse due to Fran Bow’s level design, which assembles a collection of screens for the player to scavenge through as they slowly chip away at a levels exterior until being whisked away to the next hub. At its best, Fran Bow’s puzzles are tedious and archaic, and at their worst they completely break the game’s façade and reveal the rusty gears grinding to a halt underneath.  Somehow more unpleasant to contend with, however, is Fran Bow’s second chief objective: to be as grotesque and violent as possible within the span of 7-8 hours. Fran Bow’s morbid tendencies should be readily apparent to anyone who has seen any portion of the game, but what screenshots don’t relay as readily as playing the game does is how quickly Fran Bow’s violence and gore becomes routine. It is nauseating, to be sure, but there is never any method to Fran Bow’s madness. It wants to shock and appall, but solely for the sake of proving how depraved it is. And that’s perhaps all well and good to a certain subset of player, but the point at which Fran Bow quit attempting to justify its perversions was the point they stopped being effective. Fran Bow’s horrors fail because on some level they never really aim to be horrific. At most Fran Bow seems to seek to establish a palpable unease, but the anxiety it manages to create is so constant that it can only sustain itself so long before even the sight of bodies diced and organs strewn about elicits little more than a moderate cringe.  If Fran Bow had anything more to offer beyond these two elements it might be possible to dismiss them as tolerable gripes, but at some point roughly halfway through the game, it becomes distressingly clear that Fran Bow is just as lost as the player is confused where they are being taken. From the third chapter of five onward, Fran Bow takes aggressive, woefully conceptualized measures to arrive at something approximating a conclusion. Alternate realities and timelines are employed, split personalities are discovered, characters are drawn out of the air with elaborate backstories in hand, and proceedings become radically more unhinged as the game buckles under the weight of a plot that feels more false and contrived than any of Fran’s visions. Fran Bow begins as a mysterious if meandering horror adventure game, but by its conclusion, adopts the worst narrative conventions of bad fantasy and sci-fi to form a genre blending monstrosity that is all too eager to write off every inexplicable story beat as mere madness when it is more convenient than an explanation.  Fran Bow begins with the trappings of a deliberate authorship, but by its conclusion becomes so enamored with introducing new characters and plotlines to support ones which were never well developed to begin with, that the whole game falls in upon itself. On an artistic and conceptual level, Killmonday Games are experts at finding ways to capture the players’ attention and compel them forward, but when every path leads to a deus ex machina and an exposition dump long enough to chock on, it’s hard to feel anything but regret for having gone down them.   You can read more of my writing on  Kritiqal  [kritiqal.com] .

You know, it's times like this that I wish I was able to properly express myself in words like some of the other reviewers here.  But I'll try my best... so bear with me.  I bought this game during the Steam Halloween sale. I saw the screenshots of the art style and saw the 'overwhelmingly positive' review rating and thought it might be worth my time to try it out. After finishing it, I must say, this game doesn't disappoint.  First off, the art in this game is utterly amazing. It very much resembles the hand drawn art you'd find in a children's storybook. That's actually what makes it so interesting as well because the story of the game itself almost contradicts the storybook art style. In fact, the game gets quite dark and gory at parts. This is what I think makes this game quite unique.  Of course, the excellent music and sound effects also share some success in helping to set up the mood for each scene as well.  All in all, excellent story, wonderful characters, great puzzles throughout, and overall a thoroughly entertaining game even if it is a bit on the dark side.

This game was hands down absolutely phenomenal. I encourage you to buy this game. It will leave you thinking, puzzled, confused, scared, and happy all at the same time. I beg of you to follow the story line, if you can. Because this game takes many twists and turns that will leave you always wanting to play more, even after you finished it.

Hit the spot for a new quirky point and click. Great art, amazing atmosphere and depth to the animations and illustrations. unqiue world and plenty of brain-churning puzzles. If you are a fan of adventure, point and click puzzlers or Tim Burton-esque worlds then definitely pick this up, you won't be dissapointed.

This was a very freaky game, in the good way. It starts like a normal story, but then... It gets weird. REALLY weird. I really recommand it due to the good sides, though there are some bad sides that I think you should know before you buy.  The good sides: - The horror story is really good, and gets more interesting as you play. The boring parts (mainly chapter 3) still have beautiful scenes to keep you interested. - The story is mostly not predictable, cause most of the things that happen during the game are SO weird that you couldn't guess them unless you saw screenshots/videos before playing. - The graphics are amazing, the drwaings are really good and evil, and there are a lot of great scenes. I think the design is pretty perfect, even though personally I would give up the black blurry frame that covers the whole game. - The story manages to be pretty original, which is hard to do with the idea of 'a person wakes up in the asylum' that we have seen in many movies/games before. - If you happen to have any technical problems, the moderators in the forum are really helpful in helping you solve them.  The bad sides: - The game is VERY easy to figure out, as you are being told exactly what you need to do during the whole game. The puzzles are easy as well, there are barely any chat options, and overall you can't really fail or get anything wrong in this game. You don't need to explore too much in order to find the solution to everything, and most of the game you just watch things happen like a movie, so there isn't really any challange. This game is clearly made for adults and not for kids, so I thought it would be much harder. On the bright side though, at least the story itself is good enough to still keep you interested. - There is no voice acting for the characters, which feels a bit outdated for a point and click game that was made on 2015. Most of the story feels like watching a muted movie with subtitles, which could work for other type of games, but with point and click the whole game is based on listening to the characters. I feel like the game could be 10 times better if it did have voice acting. - Taking screenshots in this game is really complicated at the moment and doesn't work at the normal way, which is very annoying, mainly because the scenes are so beautiful and creepy that it makes you wanna screenshot the whole game. - Unlike other point and click games, on this one you can't save different points of the game in order to come back to them later. The only options you have are to continue your last gameplay, start a new game (which will delete your last gameplay), and start a chapter of your choice from the beginning. This is not very comfortable, especially if you click something by mistake, or if you miss achivements. - The main character does not have enough reactions to the scary things, including things that involve her dead parents. She is like, ok with everything, or maybe a bit angry for a moment, but the only thing she really cares about is her cat. In some points at the game it's not really believable for a 10 years old girl to simply not care or react to things. - Sadly the scary and horror scenes really repeat themselves, and even though those are great scenes, they get a bit boring after a while. There are a few that will still surprise you, but most of them just repeat in different locations.  Accoring to the credits, this game was mostly made by just two people, which is very impressive when you look at the result. I would sure want to check out their next game if they ever make any, though I hope they would fix the above problems if they do.

I bought this game because of how cute the cat looked.  Need less to say this was a pretty amazing game it's been a while since I've had to think properly, I can hear the rust falling of the gears in my brain.  Can't wait to look into more games by killmonday.
I don't know whats real anymore...
I've never seen something like this game, it's total madness. AND IT'S AWESOME! You should definitely play this game, it'll bring all yours emotions out to the first reality.

One of my fav children tale is Alice in Wonderland: story that set in surreal world, full of real life methapors, in the eyes of a clever and curious girl. And that's why i always have heart in movie/game that have a similar things, such as tideland, pan's labyrinth, yume nikki (seriously!) and of course, American Mcgee Alice.   After 7.4 hours of total gameplay time, i instantly add this game in my list. Fran is adorable. i really love how she seeing things positively, no matter how gruesome itis. and its also great how this game use a punny jokes like 'vegetative state', or 'broken heart' to explain the story.   ps: alice looking through glass is out next week. hope that movie isnt dissapointing like last time :(

Fran Bow is one of the best horror games I've ever played. And it's a point & click game, no less!  Let's see...in this game you play as a young girl (Fran Bow); her parents have been brutaly murdered and she's in a mental hospital. From there, she escapes in the hope to find her cat and return home to her aunt. You do this in classic adventure style of clicking on everything in the hope to either get it into your inventory and/or finding combinations that progress the storyline. So far, things are standard. Pretty soon, however, you'll get a bottle with 'medicine' that lets you see a different other reality (a horrible overlay...kind of like in 'song of Saya'). As such, the levels play out in a Zelda-like combination of 2 different worlds that sort of interact with each other. It's really a stroke of genius here: it strongly highlights the setting (the other insane inhabitants are being plagued by strange shadows), it sets the character (which of what Fran sees is reality?) and allows for some decent puzzle aspects (some objects need to be picked up in the 'other' reality).  The quality of puzzles is pretty decent. Most of them make sense, used items don't linger in your inventory and chapters aren't too long, so the frustration levels don't get too high. That isn't to say the game is easy: you will get stuck at times. It's a part of these kind of games, so it's not like you can hold it against it.  But while the first 3-4 hours were absolutely wonderful, I have to say that I was more eager to find out about the story than to solve more puzzles. It has seven chapters (five, of which 2 are split into two), and I kind of feel that the main story drags on a bit too long. This may be just me, though.  Probably also worth mentioning is that there are a handful of mini-games within the game. While they break the otherwise rather monotone gameplay, they feel more like tech demo's than part of the experience (yes, you can make a block puzzle game with cogs in them. Congratulations...but why is it there in the first place?). Again: it's hard to complain about getting more game, but the game is certainly long enough without it.  Still...to get back to my opening: if you are into psychological horror (meaning: horror without jumpscares) and point & click games, you will like this game. It's a bit harder to recommend to someone who is just into one of these genres...you'll have to figure that out for yourself, I guess. For me, however, it's an easy thumbs up. :-)

Alice in Wonderland meets the corrupted insane asylum.  Essentially point and click puzzle solving gameplay with a fantastic storyline, art, and music that sucks you in. Five chapters long which made for a decent amount of time played considering it's price and indie status as well as its genre-- it's a great ride! For what it is ---- 9.5/10

Amazing. Initially I was charmed by the nostalgic adventure game style, intriguing story, fun gameplay, and charming art, and the more I played, the more I was impressed by just how ambitious and detailed this game is. I can tell that an incredible amount of work and love went into this game, and I'm very happy that it both exceeded my expectations, and (based on the 100% positive reviews I'm seeing so far) exceeded everyone else's as well.  Great job, Killmonday, and I look forward to what you'll come up with next!

A Gore game without being gratuitous.  A character you will fall in love with. Visually dazzling with some solid puzzles. This is the descendent of great adventure games of the past like Sanitarium.  Handles tough subject matter with grace and dignity.  Highly Recommended if you can stomach disturbing imagery.

I usually don't bother writing reviews, but Fran Bow delivers one of the stronger experiences you can get out of a game.  Gameplay-wise, it is a well written point and click adventure with puzzles that are reasonably challenging, but not to the point you will get stuck often. The music and audio work well to set up the atmosphere, and the graphics have a peculiar character and beauty. The puzzles, audio and, especially, the visuals, are good, although they don't reach the heights of modern masterpieces, such as Machinarium. However, one should consider that this game was actually made by two people and it does illustrate what indie game developers can do.  These factors alone would make a good game, but Fran Bow stands out in two ways. First, it introduces a unique mechanic which consists of visiting alternate realities or seasons which are crucial to the puzzle solutions: In one chapter Fran can move through time by controlling the seasons, while in another three chapters she can move between what might be called a waking world and a world of shadows, the latter being a dark and haunting place where a dinning table full of candy can be replaced by mutilated bodies.  Second, and most important, Fran Bow's story and atmosphere is like a slightly more coherent Alice in Wonderland, but darker, scarier, twisted, and occasionally more dreamlike and touching, where the limits between reality and hallucination are blurred. It is set in a surprisingly rich world with five realities, peculiar creatures and places, and even a made up alphabet which you can decipher thanks to an in-game book. It easy to get engulfed in the story and share Fran's fears, sorrows, and hopes.  This is an experience you will remember for a lifetime.
Internal conflict with the world through the eyes of a pipsqueek who can see the true world.  I was spoiled by checking the game in my library and saw a preview pic of a very important moment.

Bought this game yesterday during the Halloween sale. It's got beautiful artwork (both horrific and wonderful), interesting characters, challenging puzzles, and fun gameplay. I highly recommend this game!! It's not terrifying, but it is eerie...
A very good horror adventure game. Does a great job of blending fantasy and horror.

What I love most about this game is that it shows how a horrorgame can be something more than just cheap scares or running away from a monster in the dark.   With its unique art style and compelling story, Fran Bow leads you into a magical world, in which the protagonist is not only forced to conquer her suffering and somber, but also making new friends and giving her hope to finally find her own home.  It kind of reminds me of Alice in Wonderland, considering the mental instability, and i guess the developers took inspiration, which would explain the reference at the beginning of the 5th chapter..
Great game with brilliant story 9/10

This game is amazing! I just got on today and I am hooked!!! I love the original ideas and super challenging puzzles. This adventure was well worth getting myself into. Also, I emailed the creators after having trouble loading the game, and they returned my email within hours!!! Super awesome game with a wonderful support team! Fran Bow rocks and I can't wait to see how it ends!

OK, I have never really played point and click adventures/games before. But, I like the strange and unusual and after having read the reviews I decided to give this a try.  Bottom line up front, it's creepy in a good way. Yes it's point and click, yes there is reading to do, no there isn't any FPS, no guns, no multiplayer, none of that. If you are reading this though you probably already know that.  If you like creepy, freaky, scary stuff and don't mind the lack of action then get it. It's really different and really good.

To say that Fran Bow is simply unique would be an appalling understatement. Fran Bow is technically a point & click adventure game, but it feels closer to a dark and intriguing story that you dictate the pace of. The puzzles are clever, the characters gripping, the scenery equal parts beautiful and disturbing.  I played 5 hours straight of this game in my first sitting, and while I'm anxious to find the answers to the compelling questions posed by this game; I don't want it to end.  No twitch reflexes required. No jump scares. Just an amazing story that'll haunt you long after you leave.

I can't believe it's only made by two people. This is top quality - matching great story telling with very good puzzles, most of which are solvable without too much 'adventure game logic'.   The soundtrack, atmosphere, story, characters.....all top notch.   I almost feel like I will blindly buy whatever these folks make next because I am more than happy to keep supporting their efforts.
Once I got this game to work, I really love it. :)
An amazing point and click adventure game with crazy art and a touching story.

This game was very intellegent, and beautiful. Underneath the adorable surface there is alot of interesting things that will make your brain work it's booty off. The puzzles were interesting and not frustrating, the story was very interesting, and the characters were very interesting and unique. I really enjoyed this game, and recommend this to anyone who wants to embark on a very good point and click game.

Mindblowing and interesting quest, sometimes horrifying and sometimes confusing and funny. Puzzles done just how they need to be, there`s also some moments that can give you food for thought, graphic is nice, sound accompaniment is also very enjoyable.   Conclusion - totally worth a try.
is gud creepy game with special effects , cheeky creatures and strange story  would take my daily medicine again 1-1-1 , 24/7

great game with some decent puzzles and a great story that I enjoyed a lot even though the ending wasn't very good. They also did a really good child character, Also Fran actually acted like a child unlike say clementine from twd but wasn't an annoying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like most other child characters in video games

Honestly, I believe this game is very well crafted and amusing. Even though I've finished the game twice, it still amazes me with the great graphics and flow. It's a fun game to exit and re-enter into without worrying about losing progress.

To be honest, this was one of the best point and click games I've played in a long while. The art style, the settings, the characters, everything within the game was done so well, and all the while even the cute characters added a tad more sinister to the game. From the beginning, I was rather confused on what was going on, having all of these different realities and such, but once you get further into the game and meet the villagers in Ithersta, you see how the cuteness make so much sense. While this town has all the different seasons and, to me at least, cute characters, it had some evil souls, or kamalas, which probably were not allowed there in the first place due to the terror they can cause.  I believe my favorite character was Mr. Itward, because from the start, I thought he would hurt her somehow, and when you meet him in the woods while going home, he's so kind and friendly. The moment where he took Mr. Midnight, I instantly thought that he was the bad guy I saw him as from the start, but from when he throws her a party till' the ending, he really showed just how much he cared, almost having a fatherly figure to Fran.   The only thing I would love for the game is a 'Scene Selection', so that if you want to replay a certain chapter for different achievements, or to ask more questions, you can just choose it and go off from there. All in all, I recommend this game to anyone who wants a cute and sinister adventure!~

Fran Bow is a difficult game to review.   From a standard point-and-click perspective, the game delivers wonderfully. The game manages to avoid the common problem many point-and-clicks face; ridiculous solutions or situations (kind of). Every solution to a problem you encounter throughout the game logically makes sense. The situations you come across are sensible in the way that it’s understandable when you cannot surmount a problem initially and have to find a solution. To try to explain more clearly, I’ll mention something I’ve seen plenty of times before in other games; Something is blocked by spider webs. Logically, you should be able to just move them out of the way with your hands, or even any nearby object that isn’t too large. However, the games would make you find a specific object, such as a brush or stick, to finally be able to pass an obstacle that should have been easily passed. Fran Bow manages to avoid having any of these fallacies. When I mentioned “kind of” earlier, I meant that while it achieves this, the situations are really anything but logical.   You play as a drugged out 10 year old girl with a mental disorder and a devastating experience. With this comes a story that goes further and further from reality. While it leads to a story that is unpredictable and exciting, it also loses cohesion and sense. What further hurts the story is that this lack of cohesion leads to it being very open and confusing. Instead of containing and bringing in the story at points to help the player with understanding what’s going on, it’s allowed to freely roam and becomes convoluted. It’s alright to have a story presented like this, don’t misinterpret me saying that’s a bad form of storytelling. However, there has to be understanding from the player. Maybe not initially, but eventually. There is no understanding. It’s never made clear even what’s going on. Things are abruptly introduced, and then just as abruptly dismissed or never brought up again. As mentioned before, there is absolutely zero cohesion as Fran jumps from one point to another. In the end, nothing is solved or answered, and no loose ends are tied. It was an ambitious way to tell the story, and I believe it fell completely flat. The story was a mess.  Much of the appeal of the game to me was Fran. I greatly enjoyed seeing how she interacted with things, with her thoughts drawing conclusions that would have never have drawn myself. The creators did a fine job in capturing the idea that the girl was not mentally sound. I hope to see more games try to capture the type of character she was. It was because of her that I enjoyed the game.  So, to round everything up, I’ll have to say that I do not recommend it. While the game had many good things (I did not go into the graphics, but the hand-drawn 2D graphics are appealing), the story is essential to a point-and-click game. Bad storytelling that, quite frankly, never really ended is too large of a mark to be ignored. Reading through interpretations of the story, some of them are so vastly different from one another that you’d think it was never meant to follow a specific storyline.  On a minor note, I never got any achievements after the first three despite finishing the game. Not a big deal, but something to look out for.

This is a very tricky review to write.   On the positives, there is genuine intrigue and mystery (particularly in the first couple of chapters), some interesting spooky characters, great animation and cut scene sequences, some good scares and some fairly decent puzzles in the mix.   On the negatives, that's 9 hours of my life that I'm not getting back.    I don't want to give anything away in this review but there is a serious point where they drop the ball on both the story line and my interest. I really had to drag myself through chapter three to five.  It starts out very true to the Steam adverts/clips with the very creepy asylum and the strong beginnings of a mystery, where you're ultimately trying to work out if she is traumatised and innocent or psychotic and guilty.   It then swiftly evolves into something that reminded me very much of when a child is trying to describe their dream from the night before ('and then this happened, and this strange character was there....').  There were some genuinely good escape room puzzles in this, but then there was a whole chapter of irratingly (and needlessly) long winded chapters. On a whole it felt like they were trying to mix several short escape games into one, with each chapter feeling more rushed and thrown together than the last. I enjoyed the mini games that broke up the chapters although I thought they were not in keeping with the main game itself.    I would not reccommend this game, unless you were interested in playing the first two chapters only.

Once you got over the initial creepiness of the game, it's actually an interesting story and the art style is very unique. The puzzles themselves weren't too difficult but some chapters were overwhelming. There were some parts were I wanted to stop playing because I felt I wasn't progressing. Overall the story was great, albeit confusing at times and I personally wasn't satisfied with the ending. It's definitely worth playing!
Really great game! I love the art style and the music but i KNOW this game would be perfect it had voice actors

I can't say I didn't enjoy Fran Bow, but as a story based game it leaves a bad taste in my mouth with writing decisions which leave too much room for speculations.  What I enjoyed: It's set in a very well designed world with lots of loveable and relatable characters. It's kind of weird though how the game plays out. It's supposedly a horror game, but it's barely functioning as one. The game incorporates a lot of peaceful and likeable characters and enviroments, which is very rare, but it's not a concept which can't work, and here it kind of does. With this it's easy to make a huge contrast so it's shocking elements have a bigger effect. Using this, the game switches between dark and happy themes a few times to make a world which may as well be Fran's disturbed mind, and it's presented with a gorgeous art style. Also, for the most part the writing is good, but unfortunately when it matters the most they failed to make something interesting.  It's hard to talk about what I don't like about this game without spoiling anything. So for those of you who don't want it to get spoiled, the game's story is written in a way that when you get answers it only raises more questions. And in the end you get so much ♥♥♥♥ thrown at you (trying to explain what exactly happened) that it's not only overwhelming, but feels like a very heedless way to fininsh a game. Everything which happens in the last like 10 minutes is just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and I don't mean it in a way that it's completely unlikeable, there were moments which were great and memorable, but outside of that it's really just a rushed way to try and tighten up loose ends, but it just couldn't do that with all of them.  So yeah, it's hard to explain what I didn't like, but all in all it was a pleasant experience.
It's a point n' click that I actually like... I don't like point n' clicks so that says at least something about it right?
10/10 Mr. Midnight is the best kitty.

'Yeah, I was watching (some youtuber) on twitch and he was playing Fran Bow! Do you know of it?' 'Yeah, I have it.' 'There's some really messed up stuff in there dude.' 'Huh maybe I'll go home and download it'  Big mistake. Quite frankly I'm spooked easily and I never made it out of the first chapter. The atmosphere of what I got to see before noping straight out of it, is extremely macrebe and is what one can imagine living with a mental disorder is like. Thank heavens I'm only a bit OCD and a bit ADD my goodness.  If you are not like me, and do not get spooked easily, it might be up your ally. Its just not my kind of game.  The art and shadow effects are superb, the blood that coats the walls honestly reminds me of what an insane asylum might've looked like back then, considering how awful they were back then. 'But Psi you have The Dark Desent!' Mhmm I do. It was free so I snagged it. Notice how it has no playtime.  Not my kind of game/10
This game is just so awesome, I just ended the last chapter, and I want more ! You will do yourself a favor to try this game.
Excellent game, bit creepy but in a good way very enjoyable point and click adventure!

An point-and-click adventure that's equally adorable and terrifying. The story ticks along at a good pace, but I lost some interest when we're thrust into Broken Age-esque adventure. It wraps up in the end, but this game is at its best when it sticks to the gore and dark humor.
A dark twisted (and quirky) game. always reminds me somewhat of, Alice in Wonderland. only, alot more dark, brutal, satanic. Loved it !
This is the cutest psychological horror out there.
Great game with some very nice artwork and an interesting story. Had no trouble with bugs. I wish more horror games were as creative and as disturbing as this. Would recommed to any horror fan.
Fantastic! The atmosphere and gameplay was beyond what I expected.

A story about a sadistic cat who uses LSD to induce horrors on his owner so that he can escape, only to find out that his owner is clinically obsessed with the cat due to withdrawl symptoms and hunt him down where ever he goes.
This game is so deep

I didn't care for the story at all. It was long and the dialogue was drawn out. The puzzles were unengaging and not complicated. Others may love the game, but it just wasn't for me. I also didn't find it scary, just creepy and not in a good way.

Art is consistant and appropriate. Interface is servicable but cumbersome. Themeing and overal atmosphere were well done. Story quality inconsistent. Overall weak puzzles. Ending felt rushed, empty, and meaningless.

This is a horror/adventure/point & click game. Reminds me a lot of Neverending Nightmares.   You are a little girl, some bad things happened to you, you are in a bad mental state, surrounded by hallucinations and only want to find your kitty and go back home. There are good and bad creatures, strange places, etc. So the story is basically a slightly darker version of Alice in Wonderland.   Positive: -The characters are nice. The graphics are nice. The mini games are nice. The puzzles are OK, although they can be sometimes too frustrating or too obvious.  Negative: -I can't give a good rating to this game mainly because of the extremely long and dull dialogues. There are a lot of characters that you come accross and you have to talk to almost all of them. Most of these conversations are meaningless and helpless. They talk nonsense and they contribute very less to the story because the story is not clear at the end. Believe me, they are VERY long, and VERY boring. Creatures, demons, magic, terrible dreams and a lot of 'I miss my home and my cat' cryings. You have two choices in converstaions and they have no effect at all. You always have to click LMB to go on with the conversation. For god's sake, at least give me a keyboard button or something.   - The gameplay lacks logic sometimes, which can be really frustrating. At one part of the puzzle, you try to combine two objects but it doesn't let you do it. Then you pass that stage, you do a few other things, then you have to combine those two objects this time to continue. But since you think they can't be combined, you don't bother trying the same thing again, which is the normal human behaviour. So you get stuck there just for nothing.   For those who played the game, I'm talking about    the crayon and the insect executor card. You can't combine them before you try the ticket you stole from the bar

Cluttered and confusing storyline, inconsistant tone and quality, and some very monotonous puzzles.  As much as I would like to recommend it for what it does amazingly well, it does too many things poorly.
Other people have said what is wrong with this game, I have no reason to repeat how bad the story is.

Saw the game on YouTube, was really interested as it looked like a great new point-and-click game. Turns out that it will not run on any computer with an Intel graphics card. I can't recommend a game, no matter how good, with such a glaring issue with hardware with no real warning.

I just finished this game and I have to say it is a nice little point-and-click adventure. It balances humour and creepiness very well and it quite challenging. I really did enjoy this game. It's early days, but I hope there is a sequel!
I love this game to death! It is adorable, surrealistic, but - most of all - deeply humanistic and full of symbolism. PURE LOVE. /Fran

This game is really excellent. It is the kind of game that doesn't bring answers, but many questions, that you will think about again and again in order to understand what is happening. If you love thinking, you will love this game.

I've been waiting for this for years, I played the demo when it was first available and I have not been dissappointed with the game. I am a huge fan of the Point and Click genre and this is a beautiful horror-wonderland game. The only thing I have to say negatively about this game is that I get stuck on the loading screen for a ridiculously long time, and often slows the whole computer down to the point where I cannot have anything open.  Other than technical stuff, I can't speak more highly of the game. The story was engaging and I was never bored. I was challenged and intrigued. The artwork is absolutely stunning and the soundtrack suits the game.
This game has a great storyline, nice puzzle and also riddles. One thing that you must do is only click on everywhere to find the truth.  10/10 GOOD GAME
This game was stunningly amazing, i've never seen such a beautiful game with an amazing story!

This game restores my faith in point and click adventures, as well as giving me a thrill. It is definitely creepy, but isn't just a bunch of cheap jumpscares that are scary for, like, 2 seconds and then are stale. It consistantly kept me engaged, always offering a reason to keep playing even though it was like 2:00 AM and I was really tired. It was full of interesting twists that kept me turning over material, whether it was new or old. And in the end, that's what makes it so beautiful. It makes you think. The game itself doesn't give alot of hints or anwsers as to what's real and what to trust, especially with the added question of Duotine. It's really left up to you to detirmine what you are going to say is real, and what is a product of her psychosis. The theorizing is immense, and that's awesome. i myself have a theory paper that's, like, 24 pages long and growing, as I keep thinking of new possibilities. If you haven't played the game you should do so. But don't panic about finding time, because time is an infinitely layered reality. :]

This game was beautiful, after two hours of playing I started saying 'Take the pills!' and scared my boyfriend. The puzzles arent too hard, and everything should be clicked on three times to get the full story. I love what the pills do, and I love games with different realities, switching between realities in the same area to get a different view. Honestly, I never expected this game to be so perfect as it is, and a friend of mine is downloading steam to buy this game exclusively.  This game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ beautiful.
love this game

This game was cozy to play! At the same time very creepy and disturbing. Two contrast nicely blended togheter with salt and pepper. The puzzels were enjoyable and not to difficult for the most time and really fun.  The style is charming and smooth. The story was a bit confusing, still captivating and interesting.  And Fran is so adorable!!  This game is lovely! And you should play if you like puzzle games!
This Game is highly recommended I love it so much and since it's 2:00 in the mornign this review isn't going to be long. Congrats to the developer for making a cool game :)
Want to force yourself to watch a sweet innocent little girl suffer through a cruel and torturous adventure?    Buy this.    Now.

I am a huge fan of indie games. I search through pages of steam games to find hidden gems made by small companies. This is one of those gems, and it soon became my favourite.  The protaganist, Fran, invites you to love her instantly as she struggles to deal with the world around her. You find yourself joining her on the emotional rollercoaster as you advance the confused, frightened little girl through her story, on the quest to find Mr. Midnight and solve the inumerable questions that Fran faces.  In this point and click game, parts of it are quite difficult. The game requires you to be incredibly observant so I suggest regular rest breaks so you stay focused. When you are fully immersed in the game, some parts of it can make you jump. I found myself never quite expecting what I found, even though I knew it was coming.  The themes in the game are brilliant. On the surface this is a game about a mentally ill little girl. If you dig deeper there are darker themes afoot, such as child abuse, authority figures abuse of power, and a spectrum of insanity.  I don't think there's any way of doing this game justice. The beauty of it, from the artwork to the story to the development of the characters. You will find hours of fun in this game and I can't wait to play it through again. Highly recommended.
Itward.
Pretty disturbing, but that's how I like it. Reminded me a bit of American McGee's Alice, and that's definitely not a bad thing.

Such a GREAT game!!! It was trippy and wild and colorful and thought provoking. My ONLY complaint would be how long it takes to scroll through text. The dialouge seemed off, like it had been translated from a different language, perhaps? No matter, the game is loveable if you aren't scared off by the animation and sudden transition into the 'UltraDimension'. Very creative in the way the chapters are paralelled and how the story progresses into, literally, different dimensions. I would definitely recommend!
great lore and gameplay 10/10 i could even say it is kid-friendly..?
Loved this game. So much detail went into developing the plot in this game. Definitely worth buying, even for a point and click adventure.

Love the artstyle so much! It's creepy, but soooo cute. Even though Fran encounters very disturbing scenes, she acts brave and determined to push through. Will replay this soon, yes it was that good. 10/10
This game is brilliant and thought provoking. The only things I would complain about is that it is tedious to get back to achievement spots.

It is a pure masterpiece. Thank you so much for this game. I was totally excited/scared/happy/sad/confused/curious all the time while playing. And I really regret I will not be able to experience all those feelings once again as I know the story now. Pretty please think of the Fran Bow Part II.

I love this game! Creepily charming and cute in a very disturbing way! Much longer than I expected which was a nice surprise. Even though the plot is nothing new or groundbreaking, the story is very intriguing and the drawings give the game a unique apperance. Well worth the money! Recommended.

Let me just say that one right of the bat, I recommend this game to following fandoms: fans of Alice in Wonderland (and the American McGee games), fans of coraline, fans of undertale, fans of surrealism and fans of a good horror game.  Well then let´s get started  Short Review: Fran bow is a masterpiece that deserves to be loved. It has quite some similarities with the fandoms listed above. What it is, is simply a horror point and click adventure. Howeve it has quite some unique tricks up it´s sleeve. I don´t want to spoil too much about the story, since it´s best enjoyed blind, but let me say this: You play a girl names Fran Bow Dagenhart who met a terrible fate and suffered several mental disorders, beeing held in Oswald Asylum. You have to help her find her best friend. The story is great, the characters are unique and the game is just a serious nightmare fueled drug trip. Go for it.   In-depth Review: I hope you have read my short review, because Im not going to write the same things twice, otherwise this review would be wayyy to long. People with a weak stomache beware, because there is a lot of blood, gore and other things that might disturb you and your sleep. The first half of the game just gives you the shivers and opens so many questions. The characters you meat in the first half of the game are… let´s say weird, in a good, but really creepy way. The first half of the game is propably by far the creepiest and will get you far more often than you would like to. It will turn your guts and make you ask yourself what the f* is happening. Frankly speaking it´s an amazing experience. After the first half of the game, the experience changes quite drasticly as you fall deeper and deeper into a fantasy world alice-in-wonderland-style. I was a bit dissappointed, that the amazing creepy feeling of the first half was replaced that way, however the game still tries to remind you about what all this is really about. So the horror element isn´t entirely gone, but rather towned down a bit. Don´t let that fool you though. It starts to feel like you are alice and wander trough wonderland, starting to make you question what is real and what isn´t. The border between reality and fantasy gets blurry and there is an insane amount of space to interpret and think about the meaning of all this, as well as their connection to the fran-bow-universe and ours. In short: it makes you question whether what you truly see is real. It connects so many points and just forms a well rounded and compeling lore about the whole setting and the characters. Obviously the game took quite some inspiration from other famous works, like alice in wonderland (which is even sometimes indirectly referenced to in the game). Me as a real fan of surrealism am completly amazed by this game. I Highly recommend it.
Finding a game that is captivating and as entrancing as this one is difficult nowadays, absolutely a must play.

I was constantly worried about Fran's safety and really cared if she made it to the end. The puzzles are not impossible to figure out on your own at all, if anything, its harder to find everything you need but if you keep looking everything will appear sooner or later. The game isn't too long. If you like clicking on everything more than once to see how it would react or if anything changes you might take 8 to 10 hours finishing. If you like to get all the achievments, maybe a bit longer. Anyway, very charming game, curious art style, and interesting themes.
Pills here!

I must say for how abstract and obscure this story is it is brilliant. It allows you to understand some while leaving the rest up for interpretation. It also ties the chapters together quite well. I feel the writing in this game is very much movie quality material!  I have played quite a few point and click puzzle games and I usually get frustrated because the puzzles are so impossible to figure out that I give up. This game however has good hints and while still challenging I never felt that frustration.  Highly recommended! But fair warning it is a creepy and thought provoking story.

I love the game's art style and the way Fran speaks :) Game has great story plot, music, and side theories you can find when you replay the game.. It is overall very sad and touching but beautiful at the same time and I very much recommend anyone who likes morbid and realistic but unrealistic and eerie atmosphere

This game is super creative. The writing is definitely the best part since the relationship between Fran and Mr. Midnight is adorable. Fran sounds like an innocent little kid, not an adult pretending to be a kid. I was super surprised that pretty much only two people made this game. It's an interesting, refreshing take on horror by delving into the obsurd and mysterious.
Wonderful, dark, and a lot of heart.

I had a lot of fun playing this game. I really enjoyed the sheer imagination and fun of it. It was definitely gory, and a little uncomfortable at times, but in a way I found really fascinating. This game gave me a lot to think about and I hope to see more

I first bought this game just as an experiment, but from the first moments on this little piece of masterwork has blown my mind away! Is not a simple creepy game, but it is actually a game with so many details and that's touches deep in some very troubling issues, that ranges from the abandonment to some more serious things such as pedophilia and such. Completely recommend this game!
There was not a point in this weird ♥♥♥ game that I did not love or question my sanity, 10/10 would play again.
PURCHASE. This review was negative before but it was because of a PICNIC. This game is fantastic and one of the best games I have played on steam!
A marvelous game with many good points, from animations to soundtrack. The strory is moving and captivating. Highly recommended.
Beautifully written and illustrations! Definitely will blow your mind!

It's a beautiful and a well-made game. Interesting world and characters, with a lot of attention to details. Don't expect everything to be explained to you though. Expect it to make you think.  I have only a few minor complaints:   The characters are silent (speech is text only). I don't expect voice acting for such a game from an indie developer, but some 'talking' sound effects would be nice to give more flavor to the characters. However, it plays well into speech vs thought, which adds to the whole madness theme.   The last two chapters feel weaker and rushed. Still quite good though.

Unexpectedly enjoyable to play. At a couple of points, gameplay became a little thin - too much like a fetch quest with no real substance behind it. However, this pretty dark game is surprisingly light hearted. I'm planning to play through it again soon.
Absolutely amazing. The gameplay was clever and interesting, and the atmosphere was perfect for the story.   One of my favourite games :)

What an amazingly dark fantastical game! I enjoyed it completely. You play as a little girl named Fran whose parents were murdered. You wake in an asylum and all you want is to find Mr Midnight, your beloved cat, and go home to your Aunt. Through pills and magic you travel through space and time to discover the truth of who killed your parents. It is magical and dark. I loved the characters and the game play. Some puzzles are challenging and some are straight forward and it moves along nicely. Buy this game if you like fantasy, mystery and point and clicks.

I was not expecting this game to be so good. Everything from the characters, the visuals and the music was awesome. Feels like the developers poured their hearts and souls into the game. Because of that, this game will always have a special place in my heart. Though, my only complaint would be that it felt like it was too short.
A gorgeous, terrifying fairytale-like epos. Touches upon traumatising subjects through the eyes of a child. Many different chapters to explore, each with their own atmosphere. Great, great game!
play this game if you like a good storyline, unique animation, horror and imagination!! loved this game!! im hoping that they will come out with a 2nd!!

Pros: -Great gameplay, with puzzles that are challenging, but not unfair. -Art style that lends itself well to the creepy visuals -Never relies on jump scares to be creepy. and although I wouldn't go as far as to call this game scary, the dedication to maintaining a consistent atmosphere is great. -A young girl protagist, who actually acts like a little girl. No sassy one-liners, or pop culture references, but instead a realistic protrayal of a ten year old's sense of wonder and exitement, and fear of the unknown.  Cons: -After chapter two, the story goes off the ♥♥♥♥ing rails -Chapter three was way too long, and ruined the pacing of the story. -The ending leaves too many questions unanswered, and feels a little abrupt.  Summary: Even if the story gets a little confusing, the great gameplay, and cool visuals are totally worth your money.

Coming from someone who loves these creepy point and click adventures, I definitely recommend this game! The game holds a very creepy dreamlike atmosphere and doesn't use the basic jump scare tatic to keep it unsettling. I will say certain parts of the game are a little cliche, i.e: insane asylum,creepy little girl, shadow monsters. But it also introduces very interesting 'creatures', and game mechanics that help separate it from others. The pill mechanic being one of the more prominent mechanics, allows the player to see the game in two different perspectives. The game is also very linear, when given a choice in a conversation it will usually give you the same 'ending' without much diversity, with the exception of a couple. But I don't feel that really detracted me when playing the game. The campaign takes about 5-7 hours long to complete and it took me about 10 to get 100% complete. That being said I recommend getting the game while it's on sale as they are asking $15 bucks for the game.   Story: 8/10 Sound: 9/10 (Eerie piano music for the most part, you can buy the soundtrack for $5 although I don't recommend it unless dissonant piano tracks are what you enjoy to listen to in your free time.)  Graphics: 8/10 Scare Level: 7/10 (It's fairly mild, but still spooky) Replayabiliy: 5/10 (Not really meant to be replayed unless you want to experience the story again) Overall: 8/10
hard to find out the puzzles but has a nice story and the puzzles can be fun.....PLUS THE AWESOME GORE!
I love this game to bits and it pulled at my heart strings. very dark but there is always a bright side!
Fran Bow is one of the best i've ever played. The characters are amazing and you feel so connected with them it's like your in the game yourself. Totally recommend it

PROBABLY EDITED A THOUSAND TIMES*  I recommend this game. However; I do recommend that you read my Pros and Cons and judge by yourself if the Cons don't bother you and the Pros are worth your money. This is MY point of view over the game. I'm sorry if you don't agree with me on some points.  Pros: Breathtaking storyline. You absolutely don't see any of it coming. Everything is greatly attached together in the story, it makes it truly amazing. Choices. I love that you do include choices, even though those seem to have no matter over the final course of the game. The simple act of having a choice on the dialogues makes you feel included in the story. Very clever. Lovely artwork. From the very Fran Bow to the trees, the artwork in this game is something worth noticing.  Cons: No voiceover? Bad decision. This game is half wandering around, half chatting with the characters on the game. That being said, being such an important thing in the game, it's disappointing to see that there were no voices added in the game. I do like the tiny detail of hearing the characters talk for themselves instead of just reading a dialogue. It's like reading an old book. It gets boring. As said above, half the game is wandering around. That's another strong bulletpoint. It gets tiring after a long while since it gives you no clues whatsoever, so you go wandering around and eventually give up and realise that you need to search for a walkthrough because you're lost. Puzzles too difficult. The puzzles turn your head upside down and you start paying less attention to the actual storyline itself, or even the game as a whole, because the puzzles get impossible. There's no skipping button. No hint button. It drives me crazy! I spent roughly half an hour on each puzzle, and I may be halfway through the game with luck!  As you probably figured by now, I focus more on a strong storyline in these types of games.

I know a good game when I see it. And this time I was right, again. Fran Bow is a very interesting indie point-and-click drama and psychological adventure where many of us can learn a few things about the Multiverse we live in (if you haven't already discovered some hidden truths many of us have discovered already in real life), where we can really empathize with the protagonist and really enjoy a story well written and well developed by a team of two guys.  It is amazing how just 2 persons can make a game so enjoyable and so well programmed. It was definitely worthy every penny! I would like to see a Fran Bow sequel in the future! the story definitely has so much more to offer in the future, and I trust the game developers will work on at least a second part :D
A personal favorite of mine. Simply take Alice in Wonderland and dump tons of disturbing imagery and gore onto it. If you are in the mood for something weird and sinister, give it a try!
I haven't finished the game yet, but this is immersive and different, with plenty of depth. Very much enjoying it.
I really enjoyed the weirdness and surrealism of the story, it`s so much fun!

This is the first time I've played a click-styled mystery game and I have to say I like it so far. I've completed the first chapter and it only gets more and more mysterious from there. I find the setting interesting. It's full of darkness and yet fran (the main character) brings a sort of lightness to the gloom. Despite the (spoiler alert) death of her parents she remains innocent in a strange way, the dialogue all be it limited is great and it varies from character to character. I love how the setting can go from dark and gloomy to downright evil with the click of a mouse and I love the various puzzles you go through although at times it an be confusing and kinda spammy.   Any downsides? none that I can think of. If things like gore, psychological trauma and death aren't your thing, this game isn't for you. It's dark it's twisted, not all that scary but I think it can frighten some. If you don't like reading, this game isn't for you.   To sum it all up, it's atmospheric and a pure joy. You really feel for fran as she traverses this dark world. So for I love it, but I'll put an update when I complete the game.

Great art style, atmosphere and characters. The story is interesting, but the ending is... sudden and abrupt. Reminds me of the 'poof it's gone' episode of south park. You play Fran Bow and poof it ends. Makes me wonder if that's what the developpers originally had in mind, or if they had to rush the ending for some reason. Nevertheless, this is still a very good game. The puzzles are entertaining, however, all of them were fairly easy. I hope they'll add more challenging ones if they ever make a sequel.

When I first started this game, I was asking myself 'wtf am I playing'. A few hours later, I started to become genuinely intrigued by the puzzles the game offered. The perfect balance between difficulty and not being impossible, this game hits the sweet spot of having an amazing story, amazing gameplay and unforgettable characters.
great story
Great game. Playing this game feels like going on a weird, creepy acid trip. Will recommend it to horror enthusiasts.

Puzzles were not frustrating and archaic like some adventure games. The art direction was very good. My girlfriend actually got into it. It was the first adventure game she had ever played, and is not a gamer, so I was glad that I wasn't combining the rubber chicken with the bowl of pasta to open the door to the police station 'adventure game logic' wasn't in this game. We beat it in about 2 days of casual play, but didn't have to cheat via the internet for hints once.

The best point and click game I've ever played. I got this on sale for half price but it is DEFINITELY worth full price. It took about 9 hours to complete and I did it in two sessions. It was so good that I coudn't get away. But don't underestimate it being called 'horror' because it was absolutely terrifying. 10000/10

'His name is Albert and he likes relative things'  Just one of the many hidden gems in this amazing game. The art style is unique and the story compelling. I found myself putting AAA titles on ice to finish this beautiful game.   Characters you meet along the way are interesting and each unique, I actually WANTED to talk to everybody/evervegetable to find out where the conversation would lead...   It's bizarre, I felt creeped out at times, found myself laughing out loud sometimes and immensely enjoyed even the simplest things like Fran's comments while clicking on the head of a dismembered deer.  Puzzles are relatively easy to figure out without being overly easy and I never found myself frustratingly stuck. Everything could be solved by thinking things through for a bit. Also no randomly combining things to make another thing that makes zero sense to get the thing stuck in the tree - which normally kills all the fun in adventures games.  Having played many, many adventure games in my life... this is without a doubt one of my favourites and deserves to be experienced, BUY IT, the overwhelmingly positive reviews are spot on!  Besides, IT'S FALKOR!

While this is one of the most creepiest games I've ever played, I love and adore the depth, design, and execution of the story and plot. The graphic's unique style puts that edge of suspence and charm on everything you see and do. I'm so happy I purchased this game, this will certainly be one of my all time favorites forever. <3
Absolutely amazing game. I love the artistic style.

AMAZING game! Incredibly fun and addicting. Very unique art and characters. I love everything about this game. And if you love cats, this game will be purrfect for you :) I hope there will be a second game! Definitely worth your money.

Wow... just finished.... what to say... wow!  Fantastic Indie point and click adventrure game with remarkable story and visuals. Adventure games are not my favorite usually; I tend to give up on them if they are too long or the story doesn\'t hold my interest (or there too random/hard, etc). Finished this in just under 9 hours, most of the puzzles either make sense or there are nudges in the right direction if you pay attention and don\'t rush.   I got this one due to to the art style in the screen shots (reminded me of Spirited Away, one of my favorite movies) and great positive reviews and I am very glad I did. If it\'s not obvious by the screenshots above, this game is very mature (gore, themes, etc...not for kids; very unlike Sprited Away). This is another example of an indie gem. I hope to see more from this Studio!
I choose happiness...
simplly made, dark and morbid game play.. a must to buy and play. 10 out of 10 for me.

Amazing game. The art is awesome, the soundtrack is really good, the puzzles are challenging, the story is really exciting, and the characters really gets to you. A great representative of the Point-and-click genre. Go buy this game right now, and get ready for the nightmares.

Just finished the game. Seriously this game is awesome, In your face and subtle at the same time. Story driven and very creative and encourages you to be creative too. Makes you think. Would give more than two thumbs up if I had the extra thumbs I guess I'll have to use other fingers too.
AMAZING! Great visuals, great gameplay, great story! There is not one thing I didnt like about this game!

I still don't know what happened to Fran, but this game is gorgeous! It's so imaginative; eerie, creepy, cute, ... really ♥♥♥♥ed up in any case.  I hesitated, because I was not sure if this was just another depressing and sentimental indie game about troubled people with disorders when I started in the asylum (like town of light, layers of fear, firewatch.... ), but WTF just take some pills, seriously the nightmare world is  so  good. Just buy it if you wonder.

This is an odd and ♥♥♥♥ed up little game and progression through it is challenging but rewarding. I must say I do like it though and think its worth checking out if u can grab it for $5 or less do it its worth a play. very tim burtony
One of the best games I have ever played. Story - 10/10
its reallly good! i just wish i knew what to do XD

This game is a great game and I am not sure how to interpret the story of this game. The story is open to interpretation and is not very clear cut. If you do not like stories that are ambiguous and want a clear and concrete understanding of the plot of a game then I would not recommend this for you. If you enjoy theorizing and delving into the possibilities of the meaning of something then I would highly recommend this game to you.

This is an excellent point-and-click adventure game, with a clever twist. The pills that let you toggle between the 'normal' world and the strange, nightmare realities that haunt Fran really add an interesting (and eerie) level to the experience. The game is especially creepy and disturbing during the first two chapters. The story does go off the rails into the nonsensical a bit beginning with the third chapter, but in the end I was pleased with the narrative, which I think is open to more than one interpretation. The cast of characters is great as well. If you're at all a fan of the genre, I would definitely recommend spending some time with this point-and-click horror adventure!

This game is trully amazing... it's beautiful and terrifying at the same time...  It's been a really long time since a point and click adventure has been able to keep me playing for more than a few hours!  The story is so deep and original i just can't believe it as i'm playing it!  100% recommended at any price, don't miss this!
Great game! Weird and creepy, but quite intriguing.

These are one of the best games I have ever played in a long time. This game has a story of its own and has a lot of puzzles. The developer who made this game, including the soundtrack developer. I have played this game 3 times and I have been inspired to watch many horror movies from this game.  Swear to god, 10/10

The first thing that I will say is that if you like clear cut stories and endings, don't play this game, at least not for the story.   The game has many strong points, including the art style and the horror elements. The puzzles will also keep you busy for a while, but they are not so hard that you will sit there for several hours trying to find one 'piece' of one. I would keep a walkthrough handy though, because they can be hard to figure out.   My main complaint is that the story begins to lose composure near the end, and ultimately doesn't make any damn sense when we finally get to the end. I mean, I'm not against ambigiuous endings, but I usually like some sort of clue as to what MIGHT have happened, or some sort of implication, not just some random ♥♥♥♥. Maybe it may just be because I'm not the 'arty' type, but I found the ending somewhat disappointing and underwelming and took quite a bit away from the game.   6/10
It's one of my favourite games now
I cried at the end. Lovely game!
It is just such a beautiful game. I think everyone can enjoy playing it and i would really recommend to!
The art and gameplay are wonderful! The story is nice and weird. It definitely has an Alice: The Madness Returns vibe. Took ~6 hours of gameplay to finish.

This was a wonderful journey! Easily one of the best, wierdest and disturbing storys, that i have ever played. The puzzels are a good difficulty, except for 2 or 3, where i needed to consult a walkthrough, but that might not be needed for smarter folks than me.

A strange, haunting little game. It had a lot of callbacks to old school point and clicks like Goblin's Quest 3 and King's Quest, while holding onto some intense psychological dealings and horror elements like American McGee's Alice. An odd mix, but oddly heartwearming and unsettling at the same time.

Amazing Psychological Horror !!   I bought the game during the sale out of my own curiosity and grew very fond of the game and characters. I recommend any indie game lovers to purchase this game and have fun with it. Explore it and definietly come back to get all the achievments!   Wish more indie games were like this!!!! WANT MORE!
This is one of the most ♥♥♥♥ed up things I've played in some time, and that's a compliment.

Very exciting, it's woth the money. I like the disturbed atmosphere and the plot is great. Even though it is quite easy, I enjoyed a lot playing this game and I also like the particular graphic style.

Very entertaining! The whole thing can be finished using only the mouse, lol. The artwork is twisted and helps to move the story along as we're navigating the treacherous depths of Fran's despair. There are puzzles which can be challenging at times, and things that must be found, and even a language to learn - ie tem ax ej egre sahe tem ahe nihi! Happy gaming.

Fran Bow is not only a Point and Click game, it is beautiful and horrifying jounery into the depths of the human mind. It shines a cold light on to the topic of mental health, mental health treatment, and the human perception of the world around us.  I cannot recommend this game enough and I feel that I don't have enough worlds to really do justice on how much this game left a lasting impression on me.  --Update 25/11/2016--  Even after completing the game some time ago, this game's haunting impression still stays with me.

I'm a huge fan of old school point-and-click games, and I really thought the genre died a long time ago since I haven't seen a decent point-and-click to my standards in probably 15 years. I'm very happy to say though this was a great game, I was playing it with my gf and we both nearly did an all-nighter because we couldn't put this game down. I will definatley be doing multiple play throughs. Huge reccomendenation, especially if you are a fan of the genre.
Despite being afriad of most of the things, I just couldn't stop playing.

I love this game frm my friend who got me that gift! Sometimes I got jumpscares when I wasn't expecting to see something surprise or creepy. But! I enjoyed the beautiful and cool horror art graphics and animations.

It's a great point & click adventure game with a dark and complicated back story. The art style is wonderful and quite a few of the puzzles were difficult. I had to consult a walkthrough a few times. It's perhaps a bit short for some people, it took me eight hours to complete it which for me is a suitable length. 10/10.
This game.....no shortage of WTF moments, right up to the ending. Dark, gritty, highly enjoyable

I found out about this from Markiplier's play-thru of the game. Despite having seen everything the game had to offer, I loved it enought to buy it. Even having seen it before, playing it myself was still a treat, with its blend of horror and fairy tale wonder. I love the anbiguous nature of the story, with the magical and mundane explinations for the events both having plenty of support points.   I whole heartly recomend buying this game.

One of those rare games that I can't stop playing from the moment I started, till the moment I fnished it.  Simply a masterpiece. A work of art. Not simply a game.  And also a very fun, funny, deep, phylosophical game, that's really fun to play, in spite of it touching morbid subjects.
